page.title: 03SELHAM,WESTERN ROTHER
page.content: { Selham} is a leafy hamlet one mile south of the main road to{ Petworth from{Midhurst.} It has a public house called the{ Three Moles,}several farms and a{ Saxon Church } dedicated to St.James. The Rector of Lodsworth is also Rector of Selham. The Old English is "Syla-ham", 'homestead of the wallowing places.' Selham lies low in the valley of the {Western {Rother. } In the 18th century plans were laid to make the winding stream of the {Western Rother }into a {navigable {waterway}for{barges }as well as small craft. For three years{Lord Egremont's {estate workers }eliminated bends, constructed locks and built bridges. {From 1794}lime was brought from pits in Bury and Houghton, coal from the Midlands.The last barge of{timber}was {exported}by the same route in{1871.
